channel.title: Guide to a secure password
channel.description:
[center][b][u]Intro[/u][/b][/center] Ok, we've all seen those registration pages that tell you whether or not your password is secure. To be honest, they don't know crap. They just check if you have numbers, letters, and symbols. Most 'secure passwords' is just the same password somebody normally uses, maybe with a number or symbol added to it. [center][b][u]Using Passwords On Multiple Sites[/u][/b][/center] Yes, I said normally use. There isn't ANY REASON AT ALL to use a different user and password for different sites, as long as the owner(s) don't go on the other site. For example: Its ok to use your moparscape password on myspace, because you probably wouldnt find moparisthebest on myspace. . . Its [b]NOT OK[/b] to use your private server password as your runescape password. Not only is it probably the most related example i could think of at the moment, but 80+% of servers actually try to hack you. Even if its the same username, if they figure out your runescape password, you're done. [center][b][u]Strong Password[/u][/b][/center] A good password is one like this: [code]YV8wqD7ryP4[/code]
I won't be able to remember that
There is easy ways to remember this, well, not remember, but never lose it. This code: YV8wqD7ryP4 was taken from: [url=http://youtube.com/watch?v=YV8wqD7ryP4]This funny youtube link[/url] E.G. [i]h[b][/b]t[b][/b]tp:/[b][/b]/youtube.co[b][/b]m/watch?v=[/i][u][b]YV8wqD7ryP4[/b][/u] However, you must make sure the youtube video is easy to find(remember the search terms), bookmarked, and make sure it wont get deleted from youtube for it being inapropriate(If it does, you have it bookmarked, so you can change it). You can check by looking on the day it was added, and watching the video(:)). If the video seems like it is offensive, find another. If the video has been on for 6+ months, there is no need to find another video.

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

I just have one combination of letters I can remember and use it all the time.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:18, topic:135310”][quote author=therealjdb link=topic=186771.msg1688164#msg1688164 date=1187657447]
You could also add password salting to this guide, as it’s a good way to have a strong password.
[/quote]salting is more to prevent a person brute forcing the interface or if the password has is stolen, it probably wont be correctly recoverable[/quote]

I quickly skimmed that page, and it looks like its talking about adding random bits to your password, per site, so your myspace password would be basepasswordmysp, password for this forum might be basepasswordmitb, and so on. I guess that’s “salting” in a way.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“therealjdb, post:2, topic:135310”]You could also add password salting to this guide, as it’s a good way to have a strong password.[/quote]salting is more to prevent a person brute forcing the interface or if the password has is stolen, it probably wont be correctly recoverable

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @aricshow aricshow
item.description:
@aricshow wrote:

I have tested it with LC5, and it took a little while I think 15 hours - but my memories a little fuzzy, but if it was on a word list it wouldn’t take a while, but it was mostly just an example of a password thats a ‘pattern’ in the keyboard.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

I don’t know if 1qaz2wsx would take a while to crack. Many brute-forcers start with aaaaaa or 1111111 then work their way up to zzzzzzzz.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @aricshow aricshow
item.description:
@aricshow wrote:

I like to use patterns in the keyboard like I know someone who’s password was 1qaz2wsx which is easy to remember, and would take a password cracker a very long time to crack… so long most people wouldn’t bother. But also taking your favorite quote or saying, and taking the first or last letter and make a password that way

For example:
“To be a man, you must first be a boy.”
you could make: 2b@mUm1b@B
I used 2 for to, 1 for first, and U for you, and @ for a, which would make the password a little more harder to crack, and its pretty easy to remember.

Whatever works for you, as long as its secure, and easy to remember, I like them.

Also I support the different passwords on different sites thing, but I also think if you on 200 sites, its fairly impossible to remember so many passwords. There are programs that randomly generate passwords and type them in for you on every site, the only downside to this, and the reason I dont use them is: If the program gets deleted, or you computer crashes really bad, you lose all you passwords - Luckily most sites have an option to send a new password to your email address, which would be acceptable, just make sure to have a really good password for your email that you can remember. I personally have about 10 passwords I use between sites, and that works fairly well for me.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @nicatron nicatron
item.description:
@nicatron wrote:

nice on runescape they say don’t do something easy

Example: Ur username

that means the username is Ur username
and the password is Ur PassWord

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @the_cow_slay the cow slay
item.description:
@the_cow_slay wrote:

two words Alt keys. Not all sites allow them but if they do use them!

e.g. …›

That above password looks like …> and thats what someone would think if they saw it, but i actually got that by typing “alt + 0133 alt + 0155” its cool, really confused my friends

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @Haxor62 Haxor62
item.description:
@Haxor62 wrote:

What I do is just randomly pick numbers and just remember them… I have 3 main passwords and then I add and take things away from them to make them different.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Wolfeyes217:

Remember also, Sites like Invisionfree and other well known forums it is impossible for the owner to see your password ONLY the creators of the forums (meaning where the servers are hosted etc…)

Never impossible. Invision PB has bugs just like every other forum software.

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @dragonus18 dragonus18
item.description:
@dragonus18 wrote:

[quote=“jme_009, post:8, topic:135310”]To add what mopman said,

You gave the example of myspace and moparscape. Lets say your password was discovered on moparscape and they knew your myspace page, they may try the password on your myspace.

I never use the same passwords, although I was stupid once and used a far too easy password on this site. Now it’s random numbers and letters with random capitalization. Easiest way to remember it is to write it down IN REAL LIFE and keep it near your computer and just type it in and it won’t take long at all to remember it. Currently I remember 4 different very complex passwords right now lol.[/quote]

yeah once i used the same pass for my ain and myspace that ruined my week when they found em out and impersonated me and said shit to my friends’ gf

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

To add what mopman said,

You gave the example of myspace and moparscape. Lets say your password was discovered on moparscape and they knew your myspace page, they may try the password on your myspace.

I never use the same passwords, although I was stupid once and used a far too easy password on this site. Now it’s random numbers and letters with random capitalization. Easiest way to remember it is to write it down IN REAL LIFE and keep it near your computer and just type it in and it won’t take long at all to remember it. Currently I remember 4 different very complex passwords right now lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“ThatOneServer, post:1, topic:135310”][center]Using Passwords On Multiple Sites[/center]
There isn’t ANY REASON AT ALL to use a different user and password for different sites, as long as the owner(s) don’t go on the other site.[/quote]

Erm, wtf?

Think about it for a second. The chance of a website having a vulnerability that allows random people access to passwords is what? Let’s call it 0.5%, just to pull a random number out of our ass. Now, say you use that password on 200 sites. That makes 100%!

The more website you use a single password on, the more you are increasing your chance that the password will be discovered and the more problems you are creating for when it eventually does. It has nothing to do with the owner of the websites.

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @dragonus18 dragonus18
item.description:
@dragonus18 wrote:

[quote=“XxKanexX, post:5, topic:135310”]I just take some ages/years/names and put them together.

Like if my dogs were sasha and rocky, 3 years old and 7 years old…

I’d probably do
sraoschkay37
(every second letter spells rocky, every first, sasha)

After a while of doing it I’d remember it.[/quote]
good idea

Read full topic

item.title: Guide to a secure password
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[center]Intro[/center]
Ok, we’ve all seen those registration pages that tell you whether or not your password is secure. To be honest, they don’t know crap. They just check if you have numbers, letters, and symbols. Most ‘secure passwords’ is just the same password somebody normally uses, maybe with a number or symbol added to it.

[center]Using Passwords On Multiple Sites[/center]
Yes, I said normally use. There isn’t ANY REASON AT ALL to use a different user and password for different sites, as long as the owner(s) don’t go on the other site. For example: Its ok to use your moparscape password on myspace, because you probably wouldnt find moparisthebest on myspace. . . Its NOT OK to use your private server password as your runescape password. Not only is it probably the most related example i could think of at the moment, but 80+% of servers actually try to hack you. Even if its the same username, if they figure out your runescape password, you’re done.

[center]Strong Password[/center]
A good password is one like this:

YV8wqD7ryP4
I won't be able to remember that
There is easy ways to remember this, well, not remember, but never lose it.

This code: YV8wqD7ryP4
was taken from: This funny youtube link
E.G. http://youtube.com/watch?v=YV8wqD7ryP4

However, you must make sure the youtube video is easy to find(remember the search terms), bookmarked, and make sure it wont get deleted from youtube for it being inapropriate(If it does, you have it bookmarked, so you can change it). You can check by looking on the day it was added, and watching the video(:)). If the video seems like it is offensive, find another. If the video has been on for 6+ months, there is no need to find another video.

Read full topic
